cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed for students with no prior knowledge of Arabic. It places equal emphasis on the development of all language skills: reading, writing, listening, and speaking. The learning philosophy underlying this approach is that proficiency in a foreign language is best achieved through consistent, deliberate, and systematic practice. From the outset, students are strongly encouraged to develop the habit of consistently practicing learned material.
cmCourseInfo.title: Elementary Standard Arabic
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Priority enrollment will be given to declared NMC majors/specialists.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Classes will be livestreamed per the meeting schedule. Students are assigned material to study at their own pace before each scheduled meeting. Students need a webcam and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: See MHB155H1 in Religion.
cmCourseInfo.title: Elementary Modern Hebrew I

cmCourseInfo.description: See MHB156H1 in Religion.
cmCourseInfo.title: Elementary Modern Hebrew II

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online synchronous course. Some or all lectures and class meetings will be livestreamed to enable real-time contact with the professor and classmates. Lectures will also be recorded and available asynchronously, which registered students can access on their own time. Students will have the opportunity for weekly online office hours to ask questions and clarifications about course content and assignments. Students need the ability to view PDFs or PowerPoint slides and to access online library resources and Quercus tools, including Bb Collaborate and Microsoft Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course assumes active knowledge of the content covered in NML110Y. It places equal emphasis on the development of all language skills. As the course progresses, students are introduced to the fundamentals of Arabic morphology and syntax. This is achieved through analysis of texts covering a wide range of topics. By the end of the course, students are expected to achieve upper intermediate level of proficiency.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Standard Arabic I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NML110Y1 or permission of the instructor.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Native speaker. Priority enrollment will be given to declared NMC majors/specialists.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Classes will be livestreamed per the meeting schedule. Students are assigned material to study at their own pace before each scheduled meeting. Students need a webcam and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to Aramaic grammar. Readings from biblical Aramaic. (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Introductory Aramaic

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 3hrs/week (Monday and Wednesday 4:00-5:30pm EST) and the ability to ask questions and clarifications about the lectures. Students need PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: Grammar and reading of selected hieroglyphic texts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Middle Egyptian

cmCourseInfo.description: See MHB255H1 in Religion.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Modern Hebrew I
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Those who have completed Grade 8 Hebrew (or Ulpan level 2 in Israel), MHB255H1

cmCourseInfo.description: See MHB256H1 in Religion.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Modern Hebrew II
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Those who have completed Grade 8 Hebrew (or Ulpan level 2 in Israel), MHB256H1

Delivery Instructions

This is an online synchronous course. Some or all lectures and class meetings will be livestreamed to enable real-time contact with the professor and classmates. Lectures will also be recorded and available asynchronously, which registered students can access on their own time. Students will have the opportunity for weekly online office hours to ask questions and clarifications about course content and assignments. Students need the ability to view PDFs or PowerPoint slides and to access online library resources and Quercus tools, including Bb Collaborate and Microsoft Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course covers the essentials of Turkish grammar, and introduces students to reading and translation of passages of elementary difficulty. Designed for students with no previous knowledge of Turkish. This course also serves as a basis for the study of Ottoman Turkish and other Turkic languages.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introductory Turkish

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Classes will be livestreamed per the meeting schedule. Students are assigned material to study at their own pace before each scheduled meeting. Students need a webcam and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: This course assumes active knowledge of the content covered in NML210Y. As the course progresses, students are introduced to increasingly complex morphological and syntactic patterns of Arabic. This is achieved through analysis of texts covering a wide range of genres. By the end of the course, students are expected to achieve advanced level of proficiency.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Standard Arabic II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NML210Y1 or permission of the instructor.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Native speakers. Priority enrollment will be given to declared NMC majors/specialists.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Classes will be livestreamed per the meeting schedule. Students are assigned material to study at their own pace before each scheduled meeting. Students need a webcam and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: An intensive study of various Targumim to the Pentateuch: Onkelos, Pseudo-Jonathan, Neophyti, Samaritan and Fragment Targumim. Differences among them in vocabulary, syntax and verb usage are discussed, as well as their relationship to the Palestinian midrashim. (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Aramaic Bible Translations

cmCourseInfo.description: Middle Egyptian texts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Egyptian

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule.

Delivery Instructions

This is an online synchronous course. Some or all lectures and class meetings will be livestreamed to enable real-time contact with the professor and classmates. Lectures will also be recorded and available asynchronously, which registered students can access on their own time. Students will have the opportunity for weekly online office hours to ask questions and clarifications about course content and assignments. Students need the ability to view PDFs or PowerPoint slides and to access online library resources and Quercus tools, including Bb Collaborate and Microsoft Teams.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the exegetical methods of the rabbis in their analysis of biblical texts, with special attention to issues of intertextuality. The textual and thematic topic will vary by year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Legends of the Jews (Aggadah)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to Mishnah and Tosefta, two of the three foundational documents of Middle Hebrew. In addition to studying specific features of this level of Hebrew, examining these compositions independently, and analyzing their interaction, students will examine current scholarly literature on these documents and their relationship to each other. (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Middle Hebrew: Mishnah and Tosefta

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will survey the grammar and religious concepts found within the Book Pahlavi or Zoroastrian Middle Persian corpus from late antique and early Islamic Iran. By the end of the year students will have acquired a strong understanding of the script, grammar, and syntax of the Pahlavi corpus. Some knowledge of Persian is an advantage.
cmCourseInfo.title: Middle Persian (Pahlavi)
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
NML260Y1 or NML262Y1

Breadth Requirements: Creative and Cultural Representations (1)

Distribution Requirements: Humanities

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2hr online videos/week asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 2hrs/week (Wednesday 10-12am EST) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content, and to review the Pahlavi texts read during the course. Students need PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: This course involves reading, grammatical analysis and translation of modern Turkish texts of intermediate difficulty. The reading materials are selected from a wide range of literary genres. Included is a basic review of grammar as well as more advanced grammatical topics. Course serves as preparation for advanced study of Turkish as well as study of Ottoman Turkish language and literature.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Turkish

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Classes will be livestreamed per the meeting schedule. Students are assigned material to study at their own pace before each scheduled meeting. Students need a webcam and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 30, 2020: Meeting times changed.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 30, 2020: Meeting times changed.

cmCourseInfo.description:
This course covers the essentials of Ge'ez (Classical Ethiopic) grammar, and introduces students to Ge'ez texts of elementary to intermediate difficulty.
Designed for students with no previous knowledge of Ge'ez.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Ge'ez (Classical Ethiopic)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is a flipped classroom + dual delivery course. Lectures will be given as 2-hrs online videos/week asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for a dual-delivery in-class / webinar class 2 hrs/week (Thursday 10–12p EST). Students participating in the Thursday meeting remotely need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: This course assumes active knowledge of the content covered in NML310Y. Its goal is to strengthen the students reading and writing skills, refine their knowledge of syntax and morphological patterns, and enrich their cultural background. This is achieved through analysis of sophisticated authentic texts covering a wide range of genres. In addition, Classical Arabic literary texts will be incrementally introduced. By the end of the course, students are expected to reach a superior level of proficiency.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Standard Arabic

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Classes will be livestreamed per the meeting schedule. Students are assigned material to study at their own pace before each scheduled meeting. Students need a webcam and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: Every week we read a poem by a new poet, focusing on the most famous and frequently quoted poems of the pre-modern Arabic literary tradition. Students learn how to identify meters and recognize the rhetorical tropes described by Arabic rhetoric. Poets include: Labīd, Abū Nuwās, Abū Tammām, and al-Mutanabbī.
cmCourseInfo.title: Premodern Arabic Poetry
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NML310Y1 (third-year Arabic) or permission of the instructor. Heritage speakers are encouraged to take this class, and should seek permission of the instructor.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

NML413H1F This is an online, synchronous course. Class time (Tuesdays 3-5 pm) will be discussion-based. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). A tablet and stylus will be helpful but is not necessary.

cmCourseInfo.description: Texts of significance for the reconstruction and understanding of Egyptian history will be read in the original, and analyzed for content, style, and grammar. The social and archaeological context of these texts will also receive attention.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ancient Egyptian Historical Texts

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need the ability to use the Quercus website and the Blackboard Collaborate software.

courses.name: Ancient Egyptian Religious and Funerary Texts

cmCourseInfo.description: Readings, analysis, and comparisons of selections from the Pyramid Texts, the Coffin Texts, and the New Kingdom mortuary literature; study of cultic, magical, and mythological texts relating to funerary and cultic beliefs and practices. All texts to be read in the original.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ancient Egyptian Religious and Funerary Texts

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of the poetic works of a major modern Hebrew poet. (Conducted in Hebrew) (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Hebrew Poetry

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of contemporary Persian prose, focusing on fiction, novel and short story. The course includes discussion of main elements of the story such as plot, scene, characters, theme, topic, point of view, etc. and develops the ability to analyze any genres of literary prose through analyzing different Persian short stories. (Conducted in Persian)
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Persian Prose

courses.name: Theory and Practice of Translation from and into Persian

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to theories and techniques involved in English/Persian translation, focusing on translation practice and theoretical discussions on linguistic, cognitive, socio-political, and cultural aspects of translation. Through analysis and application of translation theory, students practice the art of translation and develop awareness of issues that translators face.
cmCourseInfo.title: Theory and Practice of Translation from and into Persian

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course, which is the combination of 2 hrs online lecture and active learning synchronously. In this course, students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 2 hrs/week (Thursday 11-1 pm EST) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and participate in group discussion and activities. Students need PowerPoint, Web cam and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced Turkish language practice designed to enable students to pursue independent work in Turkish and Ottoman studies. Differences between modern Turkish and Ottoman grammar will be pointed out. Elements of Arabic and Persian grammar that occur in Ottoman will be presented.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Turkish
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NML370Y1 or adequate knowledge of Turkish

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Classes will be livestreamed per the meeting schedule. Students are assigned material to study at their own pace before each scheduled meeting. Students need a webcam and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).
